bioghist.p: John William Mauchly (1907-1980) was an American physicist who, along with J. Presper Eckert, designed ENIAC, the first general purpose electronic digital computer, as well as EDVAC, BINAC and UNIVAC I, the first commercial computer made in the United States. Together they started the first computer company, the Eckert-Mauchly Computer Corporation (EMCC), and pioneered fundamental computer concepts including the stored program, subroutines, and programming languages. Their work set the stage for the influenced an explosion of computer revolution of the second half of the 20th century.

scopecontent.p: The collection includes both professional and personal papers of Mauchly, as well as information on many of the companies and projects with which he was involved. The collection contains personal and professional correspondence; financial and company information, and client and employee files for Mauchly Associates, DynaTrend, and other business ventures; research notes and computer printouts; logs related to weather data; topical files on a variety of subjects and organizations; copies of lectures, school memoranda, and class notes; and many books, journals, reprints, technical manuals, and other published items. There are also photographs, audio recordings in a number of formats, punch cards, several videos, one film, and part of a computer. Family materials include drafting drawings by S. J. Mauchly and family correspondence.
